steps.title: Step 2
steps.description: Determine need for carotid sinus massage i.e. stable SVT and the hospital is more than

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: Ensure ECG is correctly attached & print a rhythm strip

steps.title: Step 7
steps.description: Prepare cardiac arrest drugs and intubation equipment

steps.title: Step 10
steps.description: Position patient supine with head turned slightly to one side (usually to the left)

steps.title: Step 11
steps.description: Correctly locate the carotid sinus: paratracheal, 1–2cm superior to thyroid cartilage, ensuring pulsation can be palpated

steps.title: Step 12
steps.description: Perform a firm, up-and-down massage with two fingers over the carotid sinus for 10 seconds

steps.title: Step 14
steps.description: Release pressure immediately if heart rate begins to slow

steps.title: Step 15
steps.description: If unsuccessful, wait 10 seconds and repeat procedure at the same site (attempt up to 3 times)

steps.title: Step 16
steps.description: If still unsuccessful, repeat steps 2.2 – 2.6 on alternate carotid sinus (up to 3 times)

steps.title: Step 17
steps.description: Both carotid sinuses should never be massaged simultaneously

steps.title: Step 18
steps.description: Once successful, take a complete set of vital signs & print an ECG strip

steps.title: Step 19
steps.description: If unsuccessful, and patient remains stable, consider adenosine (if no contra-indications)

steps.title: Step 20
steps.description: Be prepared for synchronized cardioversion in the event that the patient becomes unstable

steps.title: Step 1
steps.description: Determine the need for EJV cannulation (Rule out Contra Indications)

steps.title: Step 3
steps.description: Ensure that correct fluid and administration set has been selected and correctly assembled and that there are no bubbles in the admin set.

steps.title: Step 4
steps.description: Place the patient supine (head down optional)

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: Turn the patient’s head to the side opposite the intended venipuncture site (i.e. medical patients)

steps.title: Step 6

steps.title: Step 8
steps.description: Align the needle in the direction of the vein

steps.title: Step 9
steps.description: Place a finger on the vein just above the clavicle to improve jugular vein distension or other appropriate vein distension technique

steps.title: Step 10
steps.description: Puncture the vein (as for a normal peripheral line) midway between the angle of the jaw and the mid-clavicular line

steps.title: Step 11
steps.description: Advance needle until back-flow is present

steps.title: Step 12
steps.description: Slide catheter over needle into vein and withdraw needle

steps.title: Step 14
steps.description: Secure the line, but do not apply circumferential dressing around the neck

steps.title: Step 1
steps.description: The student verbalises that he will evaluate the patient for predictors of difficult bag-valve-mask (BVM) ventilation using the ‘BOOTS’ mnemonic.

steps.title: Step 2
steps.description: B – Beard and other mask seal issues (facial jewellery): student examines patient and reports on finding on a thick beard or facial pathology (i.e. trauma) that may create difficulty when obtaining an adequate seal.

steps.title: Step 3
steps.description: O – Obesity: student examines patient and reports on finding the patient’s obese state may have the potential to decrease chest wall compliance, decreased ability to extend the head, and redundant soft tissue in pharynx.

steps.title: Step 4
steps.description: O – Old (>55 years): student examines patient and reports on finding that the patients age may affect the range of motion of the neck and temporo-mandibular

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: joint, associated loss soft tissue elasticity that affect the architecture of the mouth.

steps.title: Step 6
steps.description: T – Toothless: student examines patient and reports on finding that missing teeth may affect the facial architecture causing tissue collapse around the corners of the mouth.

steps.title: Step 7
steps.description: S – Sounds: student examines patient and reports on finding that he hears snoring or stridor which may be associated with abnormal upper and lower airway sounds.

Prediction of difficult bag valve mask v.sourceFile: Prediction of difficult bag valve mask ventilations.docx

steps.title: Step 1
steps.description: The student verbalises that he will evaluate the patient for predictors of difficult direct laryngoscopy using the ‘MMAP’ mnemonic.

steps.title: Step 2
steps.description: M – Mallampati classification: in the awake, sitting and cooperative patient, the student asks the patient to open his mouth fully, and to extrude the tongue without phonating. The student then verbalises what structures are visible and scores the patient according to the class. The student then reports on the predicted difficulty.

steps.title: Step 3
steps.description: M – Measures 3-3-1: student assess the thyromental span by placing three fingers breadths (patient’s diameter) between the patient’s mentum of the chin and superior border of the thyroid cartilage. Student then opens the patient’s mouth and should be able to place 3 finger breadths between the teeth of the mandible and the teeth of the maxilla.

steps.title: Step 4
steps.description: A – Atlanto –occipital extension:  in the absence of C-spine precautions the student flexes the patient’s neck at the cervico-thoracic junction, extends the head at the atlanto-occipital junction and reports on the range of motion.

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: P - Pathology: student examines patient and reports on any pathology that may be obstructing the airway (medical or traumatic origin)

steps.title: Step 1
steps.description: Takes, or verbalizes, body  substance isolation precautions

steps.title: Step 2
steps.description: Make sure the person is comfortable and tell them what you're doing.

steps.title: Step 3
steps.description: Work from the side of the injury so you don't have to lean across their body.

steps.title: Step 4
steps.description: Keep the injured part of the body supported in the position it'll be in when the bandage is on.

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: Use the right size bandage – different parts of the body need different widths of bandage.

steps.title: Step 6
steps.description: Avoid covering fingers or toes when bandaging a limb so you can easily check the circulation.

steps.title: Step 7
steps.description: Apply the bandage firmly, but not tightly, and secure the end by folding it over and tying a knot in the end. You can also use a safety pin, tape or a bandage clip.

steps.title: Step 8
steps.description: As soon as the bandage is on, ask if it feels too tight and check the circulation by pressing on a fingernail or a piece of skin until it turns pale. If the colour doesn't return straight away, the bandage may be too tight, so you should loosen it. Limbs can swell up after an injury, so check the circulation every 10 minutes after you have put the bandage on.

steps.title: Step 4
steps.description: Aim the needle set at a 90-degree angle to center of the bone

steps.title: Step 5
steps.description: Push the needle set tip through the skin until the tip rests against the bone

steps.title: Step 6
steps.description: The 5mm mark must be visible above the skin for confirmation of adequate needle set length

steps.title: Step 7
steps.description: Gently drill, advancing the needle set approximately 1-2cm after entry into the medullary space or until the needle set hub is close to the skin

steps.title: Step 8
steps.description: Hold the hub in place and pull the driver straight off

steps.title: Step 9
steps.description: Continue to hold the hub while twisting the stylet off the hub with counter clockwise rotations

steps.title: Step 10
steps.description: The catheter should feel firmly seated in the bone (1st confirmation of placement)

steps.title: Step 11
steps.description: Place the stylet in a sharps container

steps.title: Step 12
steps.description: Place the EZ-StabilizerTM dressing over the hub

steps.title: Step 13
steps.description: Attach a primed EZ-Connect® extension set to the hub, firmly secure by twisting clockwise

steps.title: Step 14
steps.description: Pull the tabs off the EZ-Stabilizer dressing to expose the adhesive, apply to the skin

steps.title: Step 15
steps.description: Aspirate for blood/bone marrow (2nd confirmation of placement)

steps.title: Step 0
steps.description: Wearing gloves, continue body substance isolation/universal precautions Explain the procedure to the patient Obtain consent /permission to perform the procedure Identify and clean appropriate site for lancing and “milk” Allow to dry and perform puncture Apply blood to glucometer strip Use gauze to apply direct pressure Report blood glucose 80 – 120 mg/dl 4-7 mmol/l STOP STATION                                                                                                            TOTAL RESULT: COMPETENT: _____________ NOT YET COMPETENT:_____________
